Fields.DialogueText: You wanted to see me, Capitaine?
Join me up on the bridge for a minute.
Une minute?
Too long for you to stand about?
Not for you, Capitaine. I suppose I'm just curious about what's on your mind.

Fields.MenuText: I just wanted to share a pleasant breeze. The weather's wonderful, isn't it?
I just wanted to hear how you're doing. You were down there with the boilers for hours.
I just wanted to know what you thought about our patrol so far.

Fields.DialogueText: C'est une belle journée.
That's very kind, Capitaine. There wasn't anything alarming going on, though - the stress testing went as expected.
A bit boring lately, but it's nice not having Command bother us so much.
I just hope things keep going this well. A few more days without a Morgana sighting would feel like a proper vacation.
Oui. That would be nice.
Definitely better than many alternatives. Okay.
I need that transmission decoded faster, Lieutenant.
The radio room is nearly finished, Capitaine.
So you keep saying. It's taking over an hour to break a priority message from Command.
Our radio room is working as fast as they can.
Maybe something has changed, but the last time I checked, this was a warship. We should be somewhat more proficient at this sort of thing.
Oui, c'est vrai.
Thanks for that, Maillé Brézé.
Of course, Capitaine. If you keep tapping your foot like that on my deck, you will find it perfectly sturdy.
And that will be the only thing I've accomplished since I got here. Do either of you have any idea why this is taking so long?
I will find out, Capitaine.
Command is counting on us to decode priority messages immediately.

Fields.MenuText: We have to be faster.
I'll try to be patient. Just make sure you crack that message accurately.
Give me the codebooks. If you can't get the job done, I'll do it myself.

Fields.DialogueText: I agree. Wasting time in war is unacceptable.
You are not punishing them? They will never get fast enough this way.
Calmez-vous, Capitaine. Are you sure you even know how to use the codebooks?
*ALARM*
Morganas? Formidable! I was getting bored from all this waiting around. Off I go!
Damn it, Maillé Brézé, wait for me!
@BATTLE
The winds just shifted.
Bonjour, Capitaine.
Was the weather report in error?
Non, Capitaine. We just changed our course to the east.
But I didn't order a course change.
D'accord. I did.

Fields.MenuText: Put us back on our northern patrol at once.
Please explain yourself.
Are you ever going to learn that the captain gives the orders on a destroyer?

Fields.DialogueText: If I did that, we'd never get to La Rochelle.
Command has ordered us to La Rochelle at once.
I took the initiative. At least I didn't fire any guns without your permission this time!
So that was Command's message? They're sending us back east?
Oui. Lt. Moreau showed me the decoded message just a few minutes ago. We are to make our best speed for La Rochelle and resupply.
A coded priority message... just to resupply? That seems strange.
There was more to the message.
And?
But I didn't listen to the rest of it.
Don't worry, Capitaine. I'm sure Lt. Moreau will be happy to discuss those boring details once he finds you.
Damn! Looks like somebody else found us first.
Pardon? You mean those Morganas on the horizon? Maybe the message said we should expect more of them on the way.
We are definitely going to talk about this later. Battle stations!
@BATTLE
Still reading that message from Command?
Yes. Is there something you needed to report?
Non.
There must be some reason you're staring at me like that.
I'm just watching you read. You seem to be exerting yourself.
Well, it's not easy to concentrate with you standing over my shoulder.
Am I going to have forehead wrinkles like that when I get old?

Fields.MenuText: Very funny.
I don't know. Command still isn't sure if Belles age or not.
Honestly, I have trouble imagining you ever making it to old age.

Fields.DialogueText: I was being serious, but I'm sorry if that offended you.
I hope I never find out!
Hmph! I'd prefer dying young than ending up as grumpy as you.
This report is odd. Apparently they want us to resupply at La Rochelle instead of going to the depot at Bordeaux.
I miss Bordeaux!
The message isn't clear, but it suggests that a major Morgana force might blockade the Gironde estuary. That would cut off anything moving in or out of Bordeaux.
Je comprends. So they want us to keep our distance, getting our supplies at La Rochelle?
It seems that way.
I would rather fight my way into Bordeaux! And then fight my way back out again!
That's suicidal.
A few bottles of wine from Bordeaux might be worth it.
The closer we get to French shores, the heavier the Morgana resistance is likely to be.
If I see any, I promise I won't start shooting right away.
Thanks.
I'll count to three first.
*sigh*
@BATTLE
They're pulling further and further out of range!
Ring up full speed ahead. We can't let those scouts evade us.
Vite, vite, vite! Get me in range, Capitaine!
Almost there, Maillé Brézé. Here comes your shot.
Come back, Morganas! My cannons aren't finished with you!
@BATTLE
The Morgana patrols are getting worse the closer we get to the coast.
But those ships won't be able to warn anybody about us.
Not before we reach La Rochelle, I hope.
Get me more ammunition, and I don't care how many patrols I have to defeat!

Fields.MenuText: The less damage we take, the better chance we have of surviving the next fight.
That's the spirit!
I don't mind a fight, but let's use discretion when we can.

Fields.DialogueText: Fighting is about winning, not surviving.
I like agreeing with you, Capitaine. We should agree more often.
I'll do my best, Capitaine.
Put us back on a course for La Rochelle.
Aye aye. Déjà fait.
I... um... agree.
Ha!
L'ennemi est presque sa porte! Everyone to stations!
I assume you're ready to go?
I can't believe you find it worth the effort to ask.
@BATTLE
Lookout, keep your binoculars up and stay alert. I don't want to be surprised by Morganas when we're taking on supplies here in La Rochelle.
Aye aye, Captain.
There she is! France!
Slow down the engines a bit, Maillé Brézé. No collisions in the harbor, please.
Nous sommes là!
I didn't realize you had been so homesick.
Not homesick, Capitaine. Just happy to see a familiar shore.
If you say so.
I was born close to here, at the shipyards of Saint Nazaire. Sailing in these waters is... nice.

Fields.MenuText: I'm happy to see you like this. Enjoy it while you can.
Stay focused! Don't let nostalgia distract you from the mission.
We're not staying for long. Don't get too comfortable.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Capitaine. I live in the moment.
Distracted? Hardly. Maybe you should focus on the mission instead of focusing on me all the time.
If we linger, it won't be my fault.
I won't stay here any longer than necessary. I want to resupply hurry back to the fight.
Looks like the trucks are already waiting for us on the pier. Time to stock up.
Our new crew is coming across the brow. Did you get a good look at them?
Oui. They look like lazy slobs to me. Slow.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe if you fired your guns they'd hurry up.
They're moving as fast as they can. Loading people and supplies takes time.
Maybe they were kept waiting in La Rochelle for too long, eating cheese and drinking wine.

Fields.DialogueText: That's a great idea! Why didn't I think of that myself?
I can't wait here forever.
Then I hope they brought a few bottles of wine from Bordeaux for me.
Hurry up! Get on board! Plus vite, limaces!
*BOOM*
Cease fire, Maillé Brézé! You can't just start shooting like that.
Say what you want, but it worked. Look at them running to their stations!
That's not all that it did.
What are you talking about?
Morganas approaching!
You just announced our position to the Morganas.
Ça va. I'm in my home waters, so they're going to be full of holes!
@BATTLE
Ne faites pas attention à moi, Capitaine. Keep drinking your coffee.
You wouldn't have just walked into my cabin for no reason.
Huh?
You're my Belle. If you want to talk, I'm here.
Some of the new crew don't like me. They keep avoiding me.
You did make a strange first impression.
Huh? Comment?
You already forgot? Firing your guns at them to hurry them aboard?
Oh, that? C'est n'importe quoi! I wasn't shooting at them. I was just shooting. Stop being ridiculous.

Fields.MenuText: Many sailors have never seen a Belle before. The first time can be a strange experience for some people.
They will get more comfortable once they get to know you.
They might be nervous. You do have a reputation for... impulsive behavior.

Fields.DialogueText: If that's true, it still seems like they're taking a long time to get used to me.
You think so? Don't lie to me.
What? Non! I'm much calmer now - I even signaled the old crew before firing the guns to startle the new crew!
Besides, this ship is fast, violent, and proud. Any real sailor should feel at home.
Just relax. It took time for the two of us to understand each other, but we're working it out. Give it time.
Time. Ugh. I knew you were going to say something like that.
Because it's the right answer.
It might speed things up if they had a few drinks with me. I'm going to get some of my homemade Curaçao liqueur to welcome them aboard.
I thought we agreed that booze was...
Never mind. I guess we'll discuss that later.
@BATTLE
Maillé Brézé? Are you in here?
Unnnnnhhh...
I can smell Curaçao liqueur... and other things. I must be getting close. Maillé Brézé?
Oui, Capitaine. And please stop yelling so loudly.
Sleeping one off in the engine room? Really?
I will have you know... that I *hic* worked very hard to socialize with the new sailors from La Rochelle.

Fields.MenuText: I wouldn't call getting wasted with them on bathtub Curaçao hard work.
I'm sure some of them appreciated that.
Clean yourself up.

Fields.DialogueText: But it must have been hard work, don't you see? I am exhausted.
You didn't hear the cheering and the camaraderie? You must have been too busy reading your boring reports and paperwork.
I'm going to clean myself up now. But I was going to do that anyway, not because you told me.
Funny. I didn't know Belles could get hangovers.
I am not hungover. I am just... tired from working so hard to impress the new crewmembers.
A great impression, no doubt.
Oui.
I know that you're trying, and I like that you don't give up.
Giving up is something I cannot do.
*ALARM*
The Morganas must feel the same way. Looks like your bath will have to wait, Maillé Brézé.
@BATTLE
You called for me, Capitaine?
I did. Come into my cabin and shut the door behind you, please.
I can see the pen in your hand and the intelligence reports on your desk.
And?
And I'm already getting bored. Why not talk to Lt. Moreau about things like this?
I am trying to solve a problem, and I need your help.
Vraiment? Oh. Well, maybe I can stay a little longer, then.
Command confirmed their suspicions. The Morganas have blockaded the Gironde River.
It's an estuary, not a river.
Fine. So, a blockade...
... would cut off Bordeaux.
And it's going to trap some of our best ships and submarines in there. Those ships can't support other patrols or operations if they're stuck in Bordeaux.
More action for us, then!
That's the problem. Command's orders were secret because they didn't want everybody to know what a big setback this will be for us. It's a smart move for the Morganas to cut them all off.
Eh, bien. So what are you asking me?

Fields.MenuText: Do you think we can double our patrols to cover for the trapped ships?
Do you think we can make some friends and team up in a task force to rescue them?
Do you think we can handle this ourselves?

Fields.DialogueText: I am not afraid of more fights, but I have a better idea.
I have enough Curaçao to make lots of friends, but I have a better idea.
You mean running the blockade all by ourselves? Against dozens of Morganas?
We can break that blockade ourselves! Do or die, we can rescue Bordeaux!
Really?
You were right to get to me involved for a change. This is our destiny!
I'll tell Command that we're volunteering. I don't know how we'll pull this off, but we have to try.
@BATTLE
I know. It was a crazy idea. We'll think of something else.
Non! I think you are on to something here!
Pour l'amour de Dieu, stop looking so nervous.
I'm not nervous, Maillé Brézé.
C'est n'importe quoi. I can see you making that wrinkled face again behind your binoculars.
I'm keeping myself busy while I wait for Command's reply.
I'm so glad you volunteered us to run the blockade. Nobody will question our bravery.
Or they'll think we're insane and relieve me of command.
Do not worry about when it will happen. It will just happen. Running the blockade is our fate.
Command might say no.
And so what if they did? Would that change anything?

Fields.MenuText: Absolutely. We're not going to Bordeaux unless they order us.
I'd prefer their blessing. We might need their support.
You're right. Even if they say no, we still have to do this.

Fields.DialogueText: We're the ones in the fight. We know what needs to get done better than a bunch of boring admirals far, far away.
They have their limitations.
Then you have nothing to worry about.
I hope you're right, but let's wait and see what they tell us.
I know a way to pass the time. When I get bored, I look for a battle.
That's not what...
Là! Found one!
Don't worry, Capitaine. I won't forget to count first. Un! Deux! Trois!
@BATTLE
Except maybe a court-martial for treason.
N'importe quoi. The worst of it will be the pinprick when they slap a medal onto your chest.
@BATTLE
Priority transmission from Command for you, Capitaine. Here is the message.
Thanks, Lieutenant.
The radio room is much faster at decoding messages now.
I noticed. Our new crewmembers are making a big difference.
I'll pass that along to them. Anything else?
I do need to talk to Maillé Brézé.
At once.
This report. Hm. So Command is sending us to Bordeaux after all...
Salut!
That was fast. You already heard the news?
About Command's message? Oui! They liked our idea to run the blockade.
Or they're desperate and don't have anybody else to do it.
Même chose. Just as good for us.
From the report, it looks like...

Fields.MenuText: ... we don't have a real chance.
... we might have a shot, if we're smart.

Fields.DialogueText: When are you going to stop listening to Command and follow your instincts?
And deadly. My guns are ready to try!
I need you to prepare. We're not going to make it without a good plan and a tight ship.
I will have the guns greased and the engines ready for all bells, Capitaine.
One more thing.
Oui?
We can't be reckless. Running the blockade means finding a weak spot to punch through when the time is right. Keep control of your impulses.
D'accord. I will try to do my best.
Capitaine?
Hold fire just a little bit longer...
@BATTLE
Keep your eyes open. It won't be long before we see them on the horizon.
Bonjour, Madam.
Bonjour.
Is everything below decks ready to go?
As ready as it can be. I noticed that you've been up here a long time with the lookouts, Capitaine.
We're getting close to the Morgana line. I want to see what sort of formation they're using to block the Gironde.
I have the latest report on the Morgana blockade.

Fields.MenuText: What does it say?
I'll read it myself later.
Really? You actually read a report?

Fields.DialogueText: I read the whole thing, so I can summarize for you.
You won't have time. This can't wait.
You should have more confidence in me. I am not a fool.
Go ahead.
The Morganas have a line of nine ships across the mouth of the Gironde, plus a few patrols running up and down the interior coast.
Is there a weak spot?
Our best shot is to run at one of the sides when they are changing positions. If we're extremely lucky we'll only have to fight a handful of them, and they'll be disorganized.
Let's aim for the western side. And try to be invisible along the way.
C'est peu probable. The mouth is only about seven miles wide. We won't get in without being spotted.
Then our timing needs to be perfect. Ready to break through?
Ready for anything, Capitaine.
Take us in.
Aye aye, Captain.
There it is. We're coming up on the blockade line.
It's going to be a harder fight than we hoped... but at least the weather should protect us from bombers.
@BATTLE
Formidable! We're through!
Not quite. It looks like more of them are on the way.
Non! Impossible! The report said there was only one line guarding the entire entrance.
It's a second line, all of them bearing down on our position.

Fields.MenuText: I shouldn't have expected the report from Command to be accurate.
Look, I have to ask - did you actually read the whole report?
I should've known it wouldn't be so easy.

Fields.DialogueText: Stupid admirals at Command.
Capitaine! How could you say that? I didn't lie to you!
Et alors? Nothing important is easy. We just have to keep going.
It doesn't matter. We have to turn back.
Qu - What?!
You heard me, Maillé Brézé. We won't make it past all of them.
Our destiny is right here in this battle.
Our destiny is on the bottom of the Gironde if we don't turn around.
Keep going forward!
Obey my orders and turn around. We do no good for Bordeaux if we get crushed here.
But we can...
Now!
Aye aye. You are the Capitaine.
You still look shaken up. Talk to me.
Je vais bien - I am fine, Capitaine. I'm not about to sink on you.
Very glad to hear it.
The crew impressed me with their fighting. They would have continued if we had given them the chance.
Are you going to be all right?
This is a strange feeling. To abandon that fight in the Gironde, backing away from the second blockade line feels so wrong.

Fields.MenuText: It feels cowardly to me, too.
It was the right decision. We can't throw our lives away.
It will be even harder next time. They'll know we're coming.

Fields.DialogueText: It doesn't seem to bother you.
Je sais. We are an asset of war. It still doesn't mean I like to retreat.
I don't care if they know it or not. My guns will punish them all the same.
Listen - don't give up. The only way we'll get through the blockade is if we keep trying.
That's all I want to do.
*ALARM*
Sounds like some of the Morganas stayed in pursuit.
Très bien. I want to destroy something.
Let's show them the error of their ways for following us out here.
That... gives me an idea for later. But first things first!
@BATTLE
Yeah, well. Part of being in command is not punching the walls in frustration when the crew's around.
We are steady on course, Capitaine. Approaching the first blockade line.
Ready to try again?
Absolument. If you are ready for my plan.

Fields.MenuText: Ready to hear it.
That look in your eye tells me it's going to be crazy.
I hope you aren't just making this up on the spot.

Fields.DialogueText: Listen up. Er, I mean, listen, s'il vous plaît.
It is not crazy, Capitaine. Now just listen to me, s'il vous plaît.
Non, Capitaine. I got an idea when the Morganas pursued us into the Bay of Biscay.
We tried pushing past the blockade by sneaking across the line, but as soon as the others heard us, we drew attention to ourselves.
We need a diversion.
Exactement. We need to draw away as many ships of the blockade as possible.
What did you have in mind?
Explosions.
Um...
Like so.
*BOOM*
That elevation... you're firing our guns onto the shore! That's France, Maillé Brézé!
*BOOM*
Please do not be alarmed. I know this area, and I've arranged for warnings. Those shells will land harmlessly on the other side of the Gironde onto farmland. Nobody will be hurt.
I hope you're right about that.
And I hope that makes the Morganas believe they are taking fire from the shore. When they see the shells land in a few seconds...
Then they'll go to the wrong side? Genius!
A simple trick for simple opponents.
Let's hope it works. Get ready to run the blockade again.
Bien sûr. I await your order.
@BATTLE
It worked! We're through!
And I got to shoot some of those Morganas again. I recognized that particularly ugly one.
Now she has a few holes in her dirty hull.
A few new ones, oui.
Not much further to Bordeaux.
Mon Dieu! I can almost taste the wine.

Fields.MenuText: Don't celebrate just yet.
You've earned it, but we still have work to do.
Your plan got us this far.

Fields.DialogueText: Oui, oui. I know, Capitaine.
All the more motivation to reach our objective.
We are going to reach Bordeaux. They cannot stop us.
Be alert. It's only a matter of time before we encounter one of the river patrols.
Je sais, je sais. And the blockade may also send a few ships after us when they figure out what happened, too. Don't worry. The narrows will keep them all in range of my guns.
And us in theirs.
That does not concern me. I am not interested in evasion, Capitaine.
*ALARM*
Speak of the devil.
We can't let them get away to warn the others!
@BATTLE
Capitaine, come up here and look. C'est... terrible.
I'm here on the bridge now. What is it?
This does not look like the Gironde that I know. It looks like... a wet graveyard.
Shipwrecks everywhere. The Morganas did more damage than we thought.

Fields.MenuText: Don't dwell on it. I'm sure these ships all fought bravely.
No warship deserves to die bottled up in a harbor like this.
Focus on the survivors instead. That's why we're here.

Fields.DialogueText: I want to believe that.
I wouldn't submit to a fate like that.
I haven't forgotten.
I haven't heard from my sisters in a while.
I doubt any of them are among these wrecks. If your sisters were here, we'd have heard about it.
I appreciate that, Capitaine, but if my sisters were here, Bordeaux wouldn't need our help.
Ha! You're probably right.
Bien sûr. I know that I am.
Do you see that?
Another patrol. Let's take some revenge on the Morganas!
*BOOM*
Maillé Brézé!
Oops! Désolée, forgot to wait. Un, deux, trois!
*sigh*
@BATTLE
Keep us moving up the Garonne River nice and slow. I can see Bordeaux from here.
These narrow waters are starting to feel... restrictive.
What's that over there, tucked into the shore?
That's a submarine pen. Is there a ship taking shelter in there?
Looks empty to me. Keep going.
All the same, I feel like something is watching us.

Fields.MenuText: You're being paranoid.
I feel it, too. The Morganas from the blockade could be on us any second.
Get ready to start shooting.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't mock me, Capitaine. My combat instincts win battles.
You don't have to remind me, Capitaine.
I am always ready for that, Capitaine.
Something is sticking up out of the water on the starboard side.
That's a wrecked frigate, Maillé Brézé.
Non, behind the frigate. Do you see the periscope watching us?
Now I see it.
My torpedoes are ready to fire, but I think that's one of ours.
How can you tell?
It's flashing something. A message!
Morse code? Four dots. H.
Two dots. That's an I.
One dash and two dots. D.
Just one dot. An E?
They're telling us to hide.
Non! I most certainly will not do that!
@BATTLE
@BATTLE
Give me a damage report, Maillé Brézé.
I have taken far worse. I am, however, getting tired of waiting around.
Any sign of that submarine periscope we saw before the last fight?
Non. I was too busy smashing Morganas. Those hags keep underestimating me. Send me more to fight!
They will. At least we're keeping casualties under control.
Being aggressive is keeping us alive. So, Capitaine, where are all the ships hiding?

Fields.MenuText: They must have gone further up the river, past Bordeaux.
Maybe they escaped already.
There aren't any left seaworthy. The Morganas sank them all.

Fields.DialogueText: If they had to keep retreating, that would make sense.
If that were true, we would have gotten a report about it.
If that were true, why would the Morganas still have a blockade?
Keep searching. If there are any seaworthy warships left in Bordeaux, we have to find them.
D'accord. Keep your eyes open, Capitaine.
That's true, I suppose.
Good thinking, Maillé Brézé.
I know.
Here we go again.
@BATTLE
Ça suffit!! I've had enough of this.
We can't go much further up the Garonne and still have room to maneuver.
Turn us around now. Let's get this over with and blast our way out of here.

Fields.MenuText: You're right. We've wasted enough time in Bordeaux.
Our mission is still incomplete. I don't want to leave empty handed.
One way or the other, that blockade is still going to kill us.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad you see it my way. Why does it always take you so long to assess a situation?
Command can look for themselves. I am done with this.
And you say I'm fatalistic? Forget it. At this point, I don't care anymore.
Turn us around. We're leaving.
*CLUNK*
Ouch!
What was that?
I think I just hit something in the water!
Almost in range, Capitaine.
You look... annoyed.
I think I'm entitled.
What did we hit? A sandbar? This waterway is rife with them.
Non. I just hit something big and... metal.
Look in the water over there. Port side. That's a periscope.
A submarine?
Nothing else it could be.
Following us from Bordeaux.

Fields.MenuText: No chance that could be a Morgana?
We need to communicate with them.
Maybe they could help us fight our way out of here.

Fields.DialogueText: Non - aucune chance du tout. If that were a Morgana, I'd have sensed it long before I ran over it.
They seem too scared to come up to the surface and talk to us.
If they were fighters, they would have battled their way out by now.
Have Lt. Moreau get a signal lamp up here. If they won't come up to the surface, we'll try Morse code to communicate with them.
I wonder how many others might be hiding out here.
Once I've got that signal lamp, I intend to ask.
Attendez une seconde. I'll get that lamp.
Wait! Get back up here! Damn. That periscope just disappeared.
I lost sight of it, too.
I think I know why. Morganas are on their way here.
Oui. I can feel them.
@BATTLE
@BATTLE
All this smoke... *cough* *cough*
Capitaine?
Get me a damage report!
I'm burning... just a bit...
Damn! Lt. Moreau needs to get those damage control teams moving faster.
Non! Non. I will be... fine. The crew needs help first. Several of them were hurt in that last volley.

Fields.MenuText: You're right. The crew comes first.
If the ship burns, the crew won't survive. We need to get the fires under control.
Are you going to be okay?

Fields.DialogueText: Good. Get the crew ready on the guns again as fast as you can.
Oui, Capitaine. Let's keep the crew focused on damage control first.
The Morganas haven't dealt a death blow to me yet, Capitaine.
No matter what happens next, that was a hell of a fight, Maillé Brézé. You showed the Morganas what a real destroyer can do.
If only that were true.
What is that supposed to mean?
They still haven't seen what I'm saving for the rest of the blockade.
That's my Belle. Chins up. We don't have much time before the rest of them arrive.
Oui, Capitaine.
Capitaine, you wanted me to tell you when we were almost in their firing range...
Thank you. You know what to do.
Regardez-les tous.
So many Morganas. More than we counted on our way in. They must have brought reinforcements.
It's not the numbers that bother me - look at the armoring. These things are going to be fierce.
Et alors? Our best moment is yet to come. I am not backing down from that line.
It's an honor to serve with you.
Ha! I am not done serving.
Then ring up full speed ahead. Let's take some of them with us to the bottom of the Gironde!
*BOOM*
Great shot, Maillé Brézé! You nearly cracked that one in half. How come I didn't hear the guns fire on that one?
Mais... That didn't come from me.
Was that a torpedo?
Absolument! It must be! That was an attack from a submarine!
*BOOM*
There goes another one! And another!
There must be half a dozen submarines running with us!
Maybe they just needed somebody to lead the charge.
Écoutez-moi, Morganas! We are going to break through your lines!
@BATTLE
@BATTLE
We did it! I can't believe it, but we did it!
My hull is battered hard, and I am probably leaking, but I know these waters. We're out of that damned Gironde and back in the Bay of Biscay.
You're right, Maillé Brézé. Welcome back to the Atlantic. Congratu...
*BOOM*
Capitaine! Attention!
*CRASH*
Capitaine?
Maillé Brézé! Maillé Brézé!
Capitaine! I can hear you, but I can't see you! Call out to me!
Down here... I think I'm pinned under something.
Ah, there you are. Crew, the Capitaine is trapped under this piece of the bulkhead. Help me move it!
*CREAK*
Bonjour, Capitaine! Can you stand?
I think so.
Let me help you up.
Thanks.
Nous sommes victorieux, mon Capitaine. We rescued the submarines that were trapped by the blockade.
We did. I guess the surface ships at Bordeaux were already done for, but Command will be glad to hear that we led the submarines to safety and to fight again.
Are you all right?

Fields.MenuText: The way you used to sacrifice crewmembers, I wasn't sure you'd save me.
I knew you'd have my back.

Fields.DialogueText: I know you are joking, Capitaine. I would not lose you.
Certainement. You should know I would not lose you.
The ship would not have it. You are mon Capitaine. You I cannot replace.
Nobody could replace you either, Maillé Brézé.
Come on! This is the last of them!
